thread.title: Cap on card fees could lead to lower prices for consumers
thread.title_full: Cap on card fees could lead to lower prices for consumers | Money | The Guardian

author: Rupert Jones
title: Cap on card fees could lead to lower prices for consumers
text:
Shoppers could potentially enjoy lower prices as a result of new rules that will slash the sometimes “unfair” fees imposed on retailers when customers pay for items with plastic, the government has said.
These fees, paid by retailers each time an individual pays for something using a card, will be capped from 9 December 2015 following an EU ruling.
The British Retail Consortium has estimated this could save British businesses up to £480m a year.
In a consultation document , the Treasury said: “The government is clear that merchants are expected to pass these savings on to consumers in the form of lower prices.”
However, some personal finance experts have warned that the new regime could signal the end of credit card reward and cashback schemes as card firms seek to recoup lost revenue.
When a credit or debit card is used, a percentage of the purchase price is paid by the retailer, via its bank, to the card company. This is known as the interchange fee. While these costs are borne initially by retailers’ banks, they are passed on to retailers and in turn to the public, including those not paying with plastic, through higher prices.
The new rules cap these fees at 0.2% for debit card and 0.3% for credit card transactions. At present, credit card interchange fees in the UK are typically around 0.85% per transaction, so retailers should enjoy “significant savings”, the Treasury consultation said.
The chancellor, George Osborne, said on Monday that he was “determined to tackle the unfair fees that Britain’s businesses are often charged when their customers pay by card – fees which are often passed on to consumers”.
The EU regulations allow governments to set lower caps for domestic card transactions, though in the consultation document the UK government proposes an average 0.2% limit on debit card and 0.3% on credit card fees.
